awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Urban-dependent selection on bird song: proximate and ultimate causes, and evolutionary consequences
awd_abstract_narration: Cities are recent environments for most organisms; yet little is known about the adaptations of species that persist in urban settings. A recent surge of interest in acoustic communication in urban contexts highlights a potential adaptation of birds to life in many different cities. These studies have raised several fundamental questions regarding this potential adaptation, which have global applications to studies of animal communication and mate selection. This proposal will address three of these fundamental questions: (1) how are birds adjusting their song to the urban environment?; (2) how has song urbanization affected signal information?; and (3) are urban songs adaptive? To address these questions, this study will employ behavioral, ecological and mechanistic modeling approaches, using an established NSF model organism for behavioral studies, white-crowned sparrows. Meeting the proposal's objectives will transform the state of understanding of urban-dependent selection on mating behaviors and, more broadly, the adaptations of species that persist in urban environments. There are several aspects of the proposed study that should yield broad impacts: (1) broad dissemination of research results through community organizations, local and national museum displays, media outlets, and development of learner-centered teaching modules, (2) research opportunities for students from demographic groups that are under-represented in the sciences, (3) development of a statistical software package for simulating bird song evolution, and a workshop to train scientists, educators, and students in its use, and (4) collaboration and sharing of data with the National Park Service Sound Division, which will help national parks local to this study as well as national parks nationwide with their sound management plans.

por.por_cntn:
This research leveraged decades-long work on a common songbird across the San Francisco Bay Area (California, USA) to investigate how anthropogenic noise shapes the evolution of bird song. We found that bird song varies spatially and temporally with anthropogenic noise. Birds adjust songs in noise both in real time and across cultural generations, which can compromise salience in functional contexts.

This funded work laid the groundwork for measuring the behavioral response of birds to the newly quiet soundscape during the COVID-19 pandemic. We examined whether movement restriction during the California COVID-19 shutdown alleviated noise pollution and whether birds responsively exploited newly emptied acoustic space by altering their songs to maximize communication to potential mates and competitors. We demonstrated that movement restriction during the shutdown effectively reversed more than a half-century rise in urban noise pollution, reflecting a precipitous drop in high energy, low frequency noise characteristic of motor vehicle use. We also showed that birds responded by producing songs with greater functional efficacy and potency.

Actions taken to mitigate the threats of the novel coronavirus to human life and welfare inadvertently resulted in a natural experiment offering unprecedented opportunities to derive extraordinary insight into how human behavior affects animal behavior. The modern scientific enterprise (i.e., since the advent of portable recording equipment) has never before been presented with a change in human behavior of comparable nature, magnitude, scale and duration. Timed to take advantage of conditions arising from the COVID-19 pandemic, our work set new investigative standards to derive cogent revelations about animal responses to alteration of soundscapes by human activity. All prior work, including our own, has relied on indirect, proxy, or bounded measures to test prevailing theories. Most studies have compared behaviors along urbanization gradients. A few exceptional studies have manipulated noise levels to measure behavioral response. Even the best of these studies, however, relied on manipulations across a small area for a brief period of time. Our study design transcended the limitations of all prior work. For example, we examined 1,500 songs recorded from more than 300 males sampled from four independently evolving song populations at sites spanning hundreds of square kilometers. And, not only were we able to capture how actions taken in response to the COVID-19 pandemic altered urban and rural soundscapes, we contextualized behavioral responses according to variation observed over a time period spanning ~50 years. As such, our study readily surpasses all prior work to deliver definitive insights that are broadly representative and generalizable.

Altogether, more than 25 peer-reviewed publications resulted directly from this funded award, and data are provided within each paper. This grant also yielded a learner-centered undergrad course, a software package in R, outreach educational events at a local museum, and a biannual K12 workshop focused on engaging girls from under-represented groups in STEM.
